document_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Klebsiella Species Isolated from the International Space Station
summary_full: Ten bacterial strains, identified as Klebsiella species (K. aerogenes, K. pneumoniae, and K. quasipneumoniae), were isolated from various locations on the International Space Station (ISS). Whole-genome sequencing was performed on these strains to facilitate comparative genomic studies with Earth-based counterparts. This research aims to understand the adaptation mechanisms of Klebsiella species to space conditions, which could potentially impact astronaut health due to their known virulence and antibiotic resistance. The genome sequences have been deposited in GenBank and NASA GeneLab for public access.
key_findings: Ten Klebsiella strains (1 K. aerogenes, 1 K. pneumoniae, 8 K. quasipneumoniae) were isolated from ISS environmental surfaces.
Whole-genome sequencing data for these ISS Klebsiella isolates have been generated and made publicly available.
The genome sequences will enable comparative genomics to study adaptation to space conditions.
The study provides draft genome sequences for K. aerogenes, K. pneumoniae, and K. quasipneumoniae isolated from the ISS.
future_research_fields: Comparative genomic analysis of ISS Klebsiella strains with Earth counterparts.
Investigating genetic adaptations of Klebsiella to microgravity and radiation.
Assessing the potential impact of ISS-isolated Klebsiella on astronaut health.
Studying the evolution of virulence and antibiotic resistance in space-adapted bacteria.

conclusions: The generation and public availability of whole-genome sequences for Klebsiella species isolated from the ISS are crucial for understanding their adaptation to the space environment and for assessing potential risks to astronaut health. These data will facilitate comparative genomic studies with terrestrial strains.
impact_statement: This study provides essential genomic data for Klebsiella species found on the ISS, enabling research into microbial adaptation to space and potential implications for crew health.
